flow.context: Dustin Frandsen is GM and Partner at Moab Lodging & Property Management — he's run this 230+ unit vacation rental company in Moab, UT since 2012. He personally led their migration to LMPM software in January 2022 and wrote a glowing testimonial about the onboarding, meaning he's tech-forward, hands-on, and values partners who make setup easy. Recent guest reviews praise their maintenance team (a guy named Carlos) but flag inventory issues like worn cookware slipping through turnovers — exactly what RapidEye catches. No direct personal connection to Sam, so lead with industry proximity in the outdoor adventure vacation rental market.

gatekeeper_or_direct.label: FIRST CONTACT
gatekeeper_or_direct.say: Hey, could you get me through to Dustin? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_or_direct.note: If Dustin answers directly, jump to opener. If front desk or another person answers, stay here. Keep it short — sound like you belong.

branches.label: Dustin answers directly
Someone else answers and puts you through
They ask who's calling or what it's about
Dustin not available or voicemail

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the area. Would you mind letting Dustin know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain RapidEye. Dose info bit by bit. End with a redirect question — you ask, you control.

branches.label: Puts you through
Asks for more detail or what company
Says he's unavailable

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Sure — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. We help a couple property management companies with their inspection workflows. I sent Dustin a note — would you mind giving him a heads up?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last attempt. If blocked, don't fight it. Get a callback time or try Dustin's cell at 435-633-7033.

branches.label: Puts you through
Still blocked or take a message

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL OR NOT AVAILABLE
voicemail.say: No worries — when's a good time to try him again? Great, I'll try back then. Thanks for your help.
voicemail.note: Do NOT leave a voicemail on first attempt. Try Dustin's cell directly at 435-633-7033. If that also misses, try again tomorrow. On second miss, leave a short VM: Hey Dustin, it's Sam Parks — I work with a few vacation rental managers in markets like Moab. Give me a ring when you get a sec. Then leave your number.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Dustin — I work with a few other vacation rental companies in adventure markets similar to Moab. It's Sam Parks over at RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Sound like you're calling a referral. Relaxed. Feet up on the desk. Not chipper, not salesy. Pause and let him respond.

branches.label: No, who? Doesn't ring a bell
Yeah, maybe, sounds familiar
Bad timing, I'm busy, in the middle of something
What is this about? Are you selling something?

heard_no.label: HEARD NO — PAIN TRIGGER
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I was actually talking to another property manager running about two hundred units in an adventure market, pretty similar setup to you guys. Great maintenance crew, guests loved them. But they kept running into this thing where small stuff — worn-out cookware, a missing item here, a staging issue there — would slip through turnovers and end up in guest reviews. Their maintenance guy was basically doing laps swapping out frying pans instead of handling real repairs. And the owners would see a three-star review and call asking why nobody caught it before check-in.
heard_no.note: This is the PAIN TRIGGER. Go slow. Be vivid. Let the story breathe. After you finish, PAUSE. Let him react. Do NOT rush into the solution. Silence is your friend here.

branches.label: Yeah, that sounds familiar, we deal with that
Hmm okay, listening but noncommittal
Not really our issue, we handle that fine
I don't have time for this, not interested

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but great. Let him talk. Whatever he says, steer toward discovery. If he's vague, he might be being polite — transition to pain trigger.

branches.label: Shares what they heard or asks questions
Vague, just the name, not sure

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow afternoon? Or is later this week better?
bad_timing.note: Give two options. Lock in a specific day and time. When you call back, open with Hey Dustin, Sam Parks — we talked briefly the other day, you said to try you back.

branches.label: Gives a time, sure try me tomorrow
Just send me an email
Not interested, don't call back

reschedule.label: RESCHEDULE LOCKED
reschedule.say: Perfect, I've got that down. I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Dustin.
reschedule.note: Write down the exact day and time. Set a reminder. When you call back you have earned permission — open warmer.

immediate_pushback.label: IMMEDIATE PUSHBACK — PERMISSION ASK
immediate_pushback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be honest. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
immediate_pushback.note: Disarm with honesty. Thirty seconds is a low ask. You can hang up on me gives them the power, which paradoxically makes them more likely to listen.

branches.label: Okay, go ahead, 30 seconds
No, I'm not interested, take me off your list

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Split the objection. You're not pushing — you're asking WHY so you can either rescue the call or exit clean. Either answer gives you intel.

branches.label: Bad time, just busy right now
Not interested, don't know and don't care
What do you do? Slight curiosity

pain_positive.label: PAIN RESONATES — GO TO DISCOVERY
pain_positive.say: Yeah, it's one of those things that's really hard to solve with people alone, especially at your scale. Out of curiosity — what does your inspection process look like right now after a turnover? Are your cleaners taking photos, or is it more of a spot-check thing?
pain_positive.note: HE'S WARM. Stop pitching immediately. Ask questions. Let him talk. You want to learn: how turnovers work, who reviews photos, what falls through the cracks. Listen for mentions of LMPM, AppFolio, or any inspection tool.

branches.label: Describes their process, cleaners take photos
Mentions LMPM or their tech stack
Mentions specific pain — reviews, owner complaints, maintenance
Asks what RapidEye does

pain_neutral.label: LUKEWARM — SOLUTION BRIDGE
pain_neutral.say: Yeah, it's kind of one of those invisible problems — everything seems fine until an owner sees a review. So what we built is basically an AI layer that reviews the turnover photos your team's already taking and flags damage, missing items, staging issues — before the guest checks in. Plugs right into your existing workflow, no process change on your end. Would you be open to taking a look at it sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
pain_neutral.note: He's not sold but not opposed. Give the one-sentence solution and the low-friction CTA. Don't oversell. Let the CTA do the work.

branches.label: Yeah I'd look at that, sure
What does that cost, how does it work
We're pretty set on that, have a process
Not really a priority right now
Just send me something
I'm not the right person for that

discovery.label: DISCOVERY — OPEN
discovery.say: Totally — so just to make sure I'm not wasting your time, what's your biggest operational headache heading into this next season? Is it more on the turnover side, the owner reporting side, or something else entirely?
discovery.note: Dustin is a GM and Partner — he thinks about the whole business. Let him tell you what matters most. Don't assume. If he mentions growth, quality, tech, owners, or staffing — follow that thread.

branches.label: Talks about turnover or cleaning challenges
Talks about owner relations or reporting
Talks about tech or systems
Asks what you do or redirects

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — PROCESS DETAILS
discovery_process.say: That makes sense. And with two hundred thirty-plus units, who's actually reviewing those turnover photos? Is it one person, or does it kind of fall on whoever's around?
discovery_process.note: You're digging for the bottleneck. With 230+ units and roughly 10 staff, someone is either drowning in photo reviews or nobody is doing it systematically. Either answer is gold for RapidEye.

branches.label: One person or small team reviews them
Nobody really reviews them systematically
Mentions LMPM or a tool
Asks what we do about it

discovery_tech.label: DISCOVERY — TECH STACK
discovery_tech.say: Oh nice — you guys are on LMPM, right? Yeah, their platform's solid. So you'd already have a lot of the infrastructure in place. How are you handling the inspection side within LMPM — are you using their native tools, or is that more manual?
discovery_tech.note: You KNOW they use LMPM. Drop it naturally like you've heard it from the market, not like you researched them. If he's surprised you know, say Yeah I've been talking to a few managers on LMPM, it keeps coming up. This builds massive credibility.

branches.label: Uses LMPM native tools, some manual
It's mostly manual, spreadsheets, checklists
Talks about wanting to improve it
Asks how RapidEye connects

discovery_pain.label: DISCOVERY — SPECIFIC PAIN
discovery_pain.say: Yeah, that's tough. And is that something that's been getting worse as you've scaled, or has it always been there and you've just been managing around it?
discovery_pain.note: Let him talk. The more he describes the pain in his own words, the more he sells himself on needing a solution. If he mentions owners seeing reviews, guest complaints, or maintenance running around — those are your hooks for the solution.

branches.label: Getting worse, harder to manage
We've managed but it's not ideal
Redirects or doesn't want to go deeper

solution_position.label: POSITION RAPIDEYE
solution_position.say: That's exactly why we built this. So RapidEye is basically an AI layer that sits on top of the photos your team's already capturing during turnovers. It automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues, wear and tear — all before the next guest checks in. No workflow change for your cleaners, no new app to learn. It just reviews what they're already doing and catches the stuff that's physically impossible to catch manually across two hundred thirty units. We're working with a few PM companies now — one managing about two hundred luxury homes — and the big thing they keep saying is it's like having an extra set of eyes on every single unit.
solution_position.note: Keep it brief but specific. Reference the 200 luxury homes for social proof. Don't go into deep technical details unless he asks. Transition to booking.

branches.label: That's interesting, tell me more
How does it actually work, technical questions
What does it cost
We might have something similar, already covered
Sounds cool but not right now
Send me info

technical_detail.label: TECHNICAL QUESTIONS
technical_detail.say: Yeah totally — the short version is your cleaners take photos like they already do, those come to us through your PMS or a simple upload, and our AI compares them against the baseline for that unit. It flags anything off — missing items, new damage, staging errors — and generates a report before check-in. We also have a video walkthrough option where you just walk through the unit with your phone and we do change detection on the whole space. All of that is way easier to show than tell though — would you be open to a quick fifteen-minute walkthrough? I can show you exactly how it'd plug into your LMPM setup.
technical_detail.note: He's asking technical questions — great sign. Answer briefly then pivot to booking the demo. Don't get sucked into a 20-minute technical conversation on a cold call. The goal is still the meeting.

branches.label: Yeah let's set something up
More questions, still evaluating
Send me info first

cost_deflect.label: COST QUESTION
cost_deflect.say: Yeah, good question. Honestly it depends a lot on your unit count and how you'd want to roll it out — some companies start with a chunk of their portfolio to test it. I don't want to throw out a number without understanding your setup better. Would it make sense to do a quick fifteen-minute call where I can walk you through it and give you a real quote? No pressure — worst case you see what's out there.
cost_deflect.note: Never give pricing on a cold call. Deflect to the meeting. If he pushes hard on price, say It's typically a fraction of what a missed damage claim costs you, but I really want to give you an accurate number.

branches.label: Okay let's set it up
Just ballpark me
Send me info
Not in the budget

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspection quality just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Because honestly I get it either way.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise him. Then split the objection into two easy options that both give you an opening. Don't argue. Don't pitch harder.

branches.label: Not a priority, other things going on
Hate cold calls, just not interested
Actually what do you do exactly

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Just so I'm not bugging you for no reason — is it that budget for this cycle is completely spoken for, or is it more that anything you try to buy has to clearly pay for itself before you'd pull the trigger?
objection_no_budget.note: Agree then split. Dustin is GM and Partner so he likely IS the approval authority. If budget is locked, pivot to test drive for future planning. If he needs to see ROI first, that's actually an opening — the demo shows ROI.

branches.label: Budget is locked, not spending right now
It's more about proving ROI, need to see value first
What does it cost

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with two hundred thirty-plus properties you'd have to have something in place. Just so I know — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache even if something better existed?
objection_have_process.note: Agree then split. Nobody managing 230 units is fully covered and happy with inspections. If he says happy, pivot to value offer. If switching is the issue, address onboarding ease — you know he values easy setup from his LMPM testimonial.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
Switching is a headache, don't want to change
What would be different about yours

onboarding_ease.label: EASY ONBOARDING PITCH
onboarding_ease.say: Totally hear you — and honestly that's the thing I hear most. Nobody wants another tool that takes three months to set up. The whole point of how we built this is there's zero workflow change for your team. Your cleaners keep taking photos the same way they already do. We just plug in and add the AI review layer on top. Most companies are up and running in a couple days, not months. Would it be worth fifteen minutes to at least see how it'd connect to what you've already got? Worst case you know it's out there if your current process ever starts breaking down.
onboarding_ease.note: You know from Dustin's LMPM testimonial that he VALUES easy onboarding. He praised the LMPM team for staying up until midnight to get his first payment out. Mirror that energy — we handle the setup, no burden on your team. This directly aligns with what he's already proven he cares about.

branches.label: Okay let's take a look
Maybe later, not right now
Send me info

test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive.say: Totally fair — you're probably not buying anything today and I respect that. But here's what I've seen — when budget does free up or the next season hits and things get crazy again, the managers who already know what's out there are the ones who move fast. Would you be open to just a quick look — not to buy anything, but so it's on your radar? If nothing else I can walk you through what other PM companies in adventure markets are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
test_drive.note: Low pressure. Frame the meeting as intelligence gathering, not a sales pitch. The steal some ideas line works because it makes the meeting valuable even if they never buy.

branches.label: Alright sure, that's fair
Send me something first
No not right now

test_drive_alt.label: HATES COLD CALLS — PIVOT
test_drive_alt.say: Ha — honestly me too. I'd way rather be outside than making these calls. Look I totally get it. Let me just shoot you a quick email with what we're doing — if it's interesting, awesome, if not, no hard feelings and I won't bug you again. What would be most useful to include so it doesn't just read like another generic pitch?
test_drive_alt.note: He hates cold calls. Don't fight it. Pivot to email gracefully. Asking what to include gives you intel and keeps the conversation going for another 30 seconds. The outside comment is a subtle nod to the fact that he lives in Moab — outdoor adventure capital.

branches.label: Gives direction, tells you what to send
Just send whatever, general info
Don't bother, not interested

value_offer.label: VALUE OFFER — MARKET INSIGHTS
value_offer.say: I hear you. Look — if nothing else, I've been talking to a bunch of PM companies in markets like yours, and I've got a pretty good pulse on what's working and what's not when it comes to turnover quality control. Would it be worth a quick fifteen-minute conversation just to trade notes? Worst case you hear what your competitors are doing and we part as friends.
value_offer.note: He says he's happy. Don't argue. Offer value instead — market intelligence. Frame yourself as a peer, not a salesperson. Trade notes implies mutual value.

branches.label: Sure that could be useful
Nah I'm good
Send me info

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox? Is it more the technical side of how it works, or more the ROI and what other companies are seeing?
send_email.note: Accept the email request then ask ONE question. His answer tells you what he cares about — technical versus business case. Include a specific time suggestion in the email for a follow-up call.

branches.label: Gives direction — technical, ROI, etc
Just send whatever, general overview
Actually just tell me now, opens up

send_email_close.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED
send_email_close.say: Perfect — I'll put something together and shoot it to you today. Is dustin at moabpg dot com still the best one? Great. And I'll suggest a couple times to connect next week in case you want to dig deeper. Really appreciate your time, Dustin.
send_email_close.note: Confirm the email address. His known email is dustin@moabpg.com. Include in the email: personalized note referencing their scale and LMPM setup, one-pager on RapidEye, two specific time slots for a follow-up call. Follow up by phone 2 days after sending.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome — let me grab my calendar real quick. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open in the afternoon. What works better for you?
book_meeting.note: Lock it in NOW. Give two specific options. Don't say when works for you — too open. Send the calendar invite while you're still on the phone if possible.

branches.label: Picks a time
Suggests a different time
Let me check and get back to you

confirm_meeting.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
confirm_meeting.say: Perfect — I've got you down for that. I'll send you a calendar invite right now so it doesn't get lost. It'll be a quick fifteen minutes — I'll show you how it works, you can ask me anything, and if it's not a fit, no hard feelings. Really appreciate you taking my call, Dustin.
confirm_meeting.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Confirm the details, send the invite immediately, and get off the phone. Don't give him a reason to reconsider.

confirm_meeting_soft.label: SOFT MEETING COMMIT
confirm_meeting_soft.say: Totally — tell you what, I'll shoot you a calendar invite for Thursday at two, and if that doesn't work just suggest a different time right in the invite. That way we've got a placeholder and you don't have to think about it. Sound good?
confirm_meeting_soft.note: Don't let him off the hook. Check and get back to you almost never happens. Send the invite with a specific time. The calendar invite creates a commitment. Follow up the day before to confirm.

branches.label: Okay send it over
I really need to check first

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WHO OWNS INSPECTIONS
referral_ask.say: Totally makes sense — who on your team typically handles the turnover and inspection side of things? Is there an ops manager or someone who runs that day to day?
referral_ask.note: Dustin is the GM — if he's saying it's not his area, he's either deflecting or there's genuinely someone else who owns operations. With about 10 employees it might be a housekeeping lead or ops coordinator. Get a name.

branches.label: Gives a name
That's really me, I handle everything
We don't really have someone for that

referral_get_name.label: REFERRAL — GET THE NAME
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — and what's the best way to reach them? I want to put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't look like spam. Would it help if I mentioned you pointed me their way?
referral_get_name.note: Get the name AND permission to name-drop Dustin. Can I mention you turns the next call from cold to warm. Ask for email and direct number. Write it all down.

branches.label: Gives contact info, says to mention his name
Just call the main office, figure it out

referral_close.label: REFERRAL WRAP
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Dustin. I'll reach out to them this week. And if anything ever comes up on your end — or if you just want to see what other PM companies in Moab are doing with this stuff — I'm easy to find. Thanks for your time.
referral_close.note: Clean exit. You've got a referral. Follow up with the referred person within 24 hours and open with Dustin Frandsen pointed me your way. Log the referral name in CRM immediately.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand, Dustin. If anything changes or you ever want to see what other managers in your market are doing with this stuff, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Be genuinely warm. Log as not now in CRM, not never. Set a follow-up task for 90 days. Dustin has been in Moab for 12-plus years — he's not going anywhere. You'll get another shot.
